name: HD 3167
scenarioDescription:
The HD 3167 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 3167 is a star with 0.94 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.87 times its radius. It is located 154.47 light years away from the solar system.

HD 3167 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 3167 system


HD 3167 d

HD 3167 d was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 3167 d is 6.90378 times the mass of Earth. At 6.90378 Earth masses, HD 3167 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


HD 3167 b

HD 3167 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of HD 3167 b is 1.7 that of Earth.


HD 3167 c

HD 3167 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of HD 3167 c is 2.86 that of Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 3167, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by W. M. Keck Observatory.
